title: 112_hr2647
content: The Act may be cited as the "Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2011" and establishes the Witness Protection Grant Program. The "Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2011" establishes a program where the Attorney General provides competitive grants to eligible State, tribal, and local governments for witness protection in court proceedings involving serious crimes or organized crime. Evaluation criteria include lack of infrastructure, witness intimidation, and cases not prosecuted due to intimidation. The evaluation criteria for the Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2011 include homicides, serious violent felonies, organized crime presence, and other criteria determined by the Attorney General. Technical assistance is provided to grant recipients as needed. The Attorney General provides technical assistance to grant recipients for establishing and maintaining programs. Recipients must submit reports evaluating their programs, and based on these reports, the Attorney General develops best practice models for addressing witness safety, relocation, financial, and housing assistance. The Attorney General develops best practice models for witness protection and assistance, including financial and housing aid, disseminating them to states and relevant entities for evaluation and improvement. The Attorney General can restrict the dissemination of sensitive information within the law enforcement community or if it poses a national security threat. The Federal share of project costs funded by grants under this section cannot exceed 75%, with up to 50% of the non-Federal share allowed to be in the form of in-kind contributions directly related to the grant's purpose. The Attorney General can restrict sensitive information dissemination and limit national security threats. Project costs funded by grants under this section cannot exceed 75% Federal share, with up to 50% non-Federal share in in-kind contributions. Federal administrative costs should not exceed 5% of funds appropriated. Grants should achieve equitable geographical distribution and consider rural and urban communities. The Attorney General must report to Congress on the implementation of this section by December 31, 2013. Authorization of Appropriations: $30,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2016 for programs funded by grants awarded under this section. Reporting on grant-funded programs required by December 31, 2017.
